linkTarget.anchoringText: As an example, when the operational practices of Eagle Ford operators in La Salle County are compared, their practices are widely varying. Fig. 1 shows pounds of proppant pumped per gallon of fracturing fluid (lbm/gal) by the various operators in the area and there is wide range of variations. There is hence a need for consistently understanding the current practices and reducing the inefficiency through reservoir modeling and characterization of the fracture geometry through advanced slurry transport models.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Fracturing treatment practices in the Eagle Ford, La Salle County by various operators (source: IHS)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracturing treatment practices in the Eagle Ford, La Salle County by various operators (source: IHS)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Just as the operators juggle the treatment design schedule, completion plan for number of stages, cluster spacing, amount of proppant per gallon of fluid, etc. to find the perfect recipe for improving production, proppant types pumped across different basins are also greatly varying (Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Proppant types by mesh size consumption in percentages across various basins in North America: IHS Markit, IHS Markit FracDB / FracFocus.org, IHS Markit WellIQ

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant types by mesh size consumption in percentages across various basins in North America: IHS Markit, IHS Markit FracDB / FracFocus.org, IHS Markit WellIQ

linkTarget.anchoringText: The test cases for sensitivity were run on a well completed in the Eagle Ford formation. Discovered only in 2008, the Eagle Ford is one of the youngest plays in the United States. It has prominent development across various counties by various operators. The US Energy Information Administration reported 1,387 thousand barrels/day production in June 2018 and 6,867 million cubic feet/day of gas per day. The productivity has been on decline since 2011; however, with the improving prices in the most recent times, the high drilling and completion activity in the region has picked up as drilled but uncompleted (DUC) wells are being completed and newer wells are being drilled. The legacy production change from the Eagle Ford has been shown in Fig. 3 (EIA).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Historical production in the Eagle Ford basin for oil and gas represented (source: EIA)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical production in the Eagle Ford basin for oil and gas represented (source: EIA)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Deposited in a low-energy anoxic marine shelf environment, the Upper Eagle Ford was created during a regressive phase and the Lower Eagle Ford was deposited during a transgressional period. The study area for analyzing the sensitivity is a high production gas well located in the southern half of the Eagle Ford basin. The gas to oil ratio (GOR) trend in the Eagle Ford play generally corresponds to the depth of the hydrocarbons being accessed. In the eastern half of the play, deeper wells (up to 15,000 feet) to the south have higher initial GORs, or a relatively greater share of natural gas, whereas the shallower wells in the north have lower initial GORs, or a relatively greater share of oil (Fig. 4) (Coleman 2015).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: GOR (ft3STB) trend in the Eagle Ford and area of study shown marked with star (Coleman 2015)

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR (ft3STB) trend in the Eagle Ford and area of study shown marked with star (Coleman 2015)

linkTarget.bib:
Coleman 2015
M. >oleman 2015. EIA Updates Eagle Ford Maps to Provide Greater Geologic Detail, U.S. Energy Information Administration, January 21, 2015. https://www.eia.gov/maps/pdf/EIA%20Eagle%20Ford%20Play%20update%2012-29-14.pdf

linkTarget.anchoringText: Following Velikanov et al. 2018. fracture geometry is calculated using pseudo 3D (P3D) model (Adachi et al. 2007) based on 1D moving grid along the fracture length. The width profiles for the grid cells are shown schematically for a fracture half-wing in Fig. 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Pseudo 3D fracture geometry scheme (half-wing)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pseudo 3D fracture geometry scheme (half-wing)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation results for the base case are shown in Fig. 6a and Fig. 7. Due to the low viscosity of slickwater, proppant particles settled rapidly and formed a bank at the bottom of the fracture before fracture closure. However, in real hydraulic fractures the settling may be slowed down due to the presence of laminations and wall roughness/morphology, which is currently not considered in the simulator.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: base case 1 (a) and overflush 100 bbl per stage with 5 fractures (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: base case 1 (a) and overflush 100 bbl per stage with 5 fractures (b)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: base case 1
and overflush 100 bbl per stage with 5 fractures

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation results for the base case are shown in Fig. 6a and Fig. 7. Due to the low viscosity of slickwater, proppant particles settled rapidly and formed a bank at the bottom of the fracture before fracture closure. However, in real hydraulic fractures the settling may be slowed down due to the presence of laminations and wall roughness/morphology, which is currently not considered in the simulator.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Production forecast for different overflushing strategies

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production forecast for different overflushing strategies

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 8 presents calculated distributions of proppant mass per area for these cases (a, b, and c). Proppant with bigger mesh size settles closer to the wellbore, whereas smaller proppants are transported further due to lower settling velocity. The production curves for base case 2 and proppant 30/50 are shown in Fig. 8d. The results for 20/40 and 100-mesh proppants are located between them and omitted here. It is seen that proppant mesh size has small effect on wellbore productivity in the cases considered.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40 (a), 30/50 (b), 100 mesh (c), and corresponding production forecast (d)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40 (a), 30/50 (b), 100 mesh (c), and corresponding production forecast (d)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40
100 mesh
and corresponding production forecast

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 9 shows proppant distributions obtained for the additional designs. The case with sweeps has longer fracture half-length compared to the base case and more even proppant distribution along fracture length. The case with the straight ramp has similar fracture length and less proppant in fracture tip compared to the base case. In terms of production, the described cases gave similar production results, within 10% difference (Fig. 10) with a minor advantage of the case with sweeps. However, compared to the base case 1 production is lower.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps (a) and straight ramp (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps (a) and straight ramp (b)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps
and straight ramp

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 9 shows proppant distributions obtained for the additional designs. The case with sweeps has longer fracture half-length compared to the base case and more even proppant distribution along fracture length. The case with the straight ramp has similar fracture length and less proppant in fracture tip compared to the base case. In terms of production, the described cases gave similar production results, within 10% difference (Fig. 10) with a minor advantage of the case with sweeps. However, compared to the base case 1 production is lower.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Production forecast for the designs with and without sweeps

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production forecast for the designs with and without sweeps

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 11 shows proppant mass per area distribution for 750 and 3000 lbm/ft. It is seen in Fig. 11b that increased proppant loading leads to the accumulation of solids in the near-wellbore area caused by their bridging at high concentrations. This results in larger propped width near the perforations, but smaller propped fracture area, which has a negative impact on production as shown in Fig. 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft
and 3000 lbm/ft

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 11 shows proppant mass per area distribution for 750 and 3000 lbm/ft. It is seen in Fig. 11b that increased proppant loading leads to the accumulation of solids in the near-wellbore area caused by their bridging at high concentrations. This results in larger propped width near the perforations, but smaller propped fracture area, which has a negative impact on production as shown in Fig. 12.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The design for this case is obtained from pumping schedule given in Table 2 after replacing the treatment fluid to linear gel (K = 4E-4 lbf.sn/ft2 and n = 0.9). The leakoff properties are taken from base case 1. The simulation results for the base case 2 are shown in Fig. 13a and Fig. 14. Compared to base case 1 proppant is transported further over the fracture half-length.

and overflush 100 bbl per stage with 5 fractures

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 15 shows proppant distribution (a, b, and c) and corresponding production results (d). Similar to slickwater cases, smaller mesh size proppant (100-mesh, c) is better distributed along the fracture half-length whereas bigger mesh size proppant is concentrated closer to near-wellbore area (20/40, a). Production results, though, are similar for all described cases as shown in in Fig. 15d. The curve for 30/50 proppant coincides with base case 2 and omitted for clarity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40 (a), 30/50 (b), and 100 mesh (c), and corresponding production forecast (c)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40 (a), 30/50 (b), and 100 mesh (c), and corresponding production forecast (c)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40
and 100 mesh
and corresponding production forecast

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 16 shows proppant distribution after closure with sweeps (a) and straight proppant ramp (b). Production results for both cases are shown in Fig. 17. Proppant placed with a straight ramp is distributed equally along fracture half-length, proppant placed with sweeps preliminarily near the fracture bottom. Production results for both cases are similar.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps (a) and straight ramp (b)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 18 shows proppant distribution after closure with different proppant loadings 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b). The production simulation results are shown in Fig. 19. It is seen that the best production does not necessarily correspond to the largest mass of proppant injected. For proppant loading 3000 lbm/ft we observe excessive bridging of solids and their accumulation near the perforations shown in Fig. 18b.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft
and 3000 lbm/ft

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation results presented in Fig. 22 confirm that highly viscous treatment fluids provide good transport of sands with different mesh size. The differences between production curves for different cases shown in Fig. 22d appear due to proppant conductivity properties.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40 (a), 30/50 (b), 100 mesh (c), and production forecast (d)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40 (a), 30/50 (b), 100 mesh (c), and production forecast (d)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: proppants 20/40
100 mesh
and production forecast

linkTarget.anchoringText: For low-viscosity fluids, the sweeps lead to creation of alternating propped and unpropped zones like those obtained in channel fracturing technology, but at a larger scale (see Fig. 23). When these channels are open, they result in good production, as shown in Fig. 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps (a) and straight ramp (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps (a) and straight ramp (b)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: sweeps
and straight ramp

linkTarget.anchoringText: For low-viscosity fluids, the sweeps lead to creation of alternating propped and unpropped zones like those obtained in channel fracturing technology, but at a larger scale (see Fig. 23). When these channels are open, they result in good production, as shown in Fig. 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Production forecast for the designs with and without sweeps

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production forecast for the designs with and without sweeps

linkTarget.anchoringText: Highly viscous treatment fluid ensures creation of thick hydraulic fractures. It reduces the risk of proppant bridging even in case of increased proppant loading (see Fig. 25). Finally, it results in good production (see Fig. 26).

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft (a) and 3000 lbm/ft (b)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution after fracture closure: 750 lbm/ft
and 3000 lbm/ft

linkTarget.anchoringText: Highly viscous treatment fluid ensures creation of thick hydraulic fractures. It reduces the risk of proppant bridging even in case of increased proppant loading (see Fig. 25). Finally, it results in good production (see Fig. 26).
